arXiv:2410.03919v1 [cs.LG] 04 Oct 2024

Online Posterior Sampling with a Diffusion Prior

Branislav Kveton
AWS AI Labs &Boris Oreshkin
Amazon &Youngsuk Park
AWS AI Labs &Aniket Deshmukh
AWS AI Labs &Rui Song
Amazon
Abstract

Posterior sampling in contextual bandits with a Gaussian prior can be implemented exactly or approximately using the Laplace approximation. The Gaussian prior is computationally efficient but it cannot describe complex distributions. In this work, we propose approximate posterior sampling algorithms for contextual bandits with a diffusion model prior. The key idea is to sample from a chain of approximate conditional posteriors, one for each stage of the reverse process, which are estimated in a closed form using the Laplace approximation. Our approximations are motivated by posterior sampling with a Gaussian prior, and inherit its simplicity and efficiency. They are asymptotically consistent and perform well empirically on a variety of contextual bandit problems.

1 Introduction

A multi-armed bandit [26, 6, 29] is an online learning problem where an agent sequentially interacts with an environment over n𝑛nitalic_n rounds with the goal of maximizing its rewards. In each round, it takes an action and receives its stochastic reward. The mean rewards of the actions are unknown a priori and must be learned. This leads to the exploration-exploitation dilemma: explore actions to learn about them or exploit the action with the highest estimated reward. Bandits have been successfully applied to problems where uncertainty modeling and adaptation to it are beneficial, such as in recommender systems [31, 53, 24, 34] and hyper-parameter optimization [33].

Contextual bandits [28, 31] with linear [13, 1] and generalized linear models (GLMs) [16, 32, 2, 25] have become popular due to the their flexibility and efficiency. The features in these models can be hand-crafted or learned from historic data [39], and the models can be also updated incrementally [1, 23]. While the original algorithms for linear and GLM bandits were based on upper confidence bounds (UCBs) [13, 1, 16], Thompson sampling (TS) is more popular in practice [11, 3, 41, 43]. The key idea in TS is to explore by sampling from the posterior distribution of model parameter θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. TS uses the prior knowledge about θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to speed up exploration [11, 39, 35, 9, 20, 19, 5]. When the prior is a multivariate Gaussian, the posterior of θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be updated and sampled from efficiently [11]. Unfortunately, this prior has limited expressive power, because it cannot even represent multimodal distributions. To address this limitation, we study posterior sampling with complex priors.

We make the following contributions. First, we propose novel posterior sampling approximations for linear models and GLMs with a diffusion model prior. The key idea is to sample from a chain of approximate conditional posteriors, one for each stage of the reverse process, which are estimated in a closed form. In linear models, each conditional is a product of two Gaussians, representing prior knowledge and diffused evidence (Theorem 2). In GLMs, each conditional is obtained by a Laplace approximation, which mixes prior knowledge and evidence (Theorem 4). Our approximations are motivated by posterior sampling with a Gaussian prior, and inherit its simplicity and efficiency. The prior works (Section 7) rely on the score of the likelihood of observations. In online learning, the likelihood score tends to infinity as the number of observations increases, which causes divergence of the existing approximations (Section 6.2).

Our second major contribution is in theory. More specifically, we prove that our posterior approximation is asymptotically consistent (Theorem 3). The key idea in the proof is that the conditional posteriors in Theorem 2 concentrate at a scaled unknown model parameter as the number of observations increases. While this claim is asymptotic, it is an expected property of a posterior distribution. Many prior works, such as Chung et al. [12], do not poses this property.

Our last contribution is empirical evaluation on contextual bandit problems. We focus on bandits because the ability to represent all levels of uncertainty well is critical for exploration. Our experiments (Section 6.2) show that a score-based method fails to do so. Note that our posterior approximations are general and not restricted to bandits.

2.2 Generalized Linear Model

Generalized linear models (GLMs) [36] extend linear models (Section 2.1) to non-linear monotone mean functions g𝑔gitalic_g in (1). For instance, in logistic regression, g⁢(u)=1/(1+exp⁡[−u])𝑔𝑢11𝑢g(u)=1/(1+\exp[-u])italic_g ( italic_u ) = 1 / ( 1 + roman_exp [ - italic_u ] ) is a sigmoid. The likelihood of observations in GLMs has the following form [25].

2.3 Towards Diffusion Model Priors

The assumption that p⁢(θ∗)=𝒩⁢(θ∗;θ0,Σ0)𝑝subscript𝜃𝒩subscript𝜃subscript𝜃0subscriptΣ0p(\theta_{*})=\mathcal{N}(\theta_{*};\theta_{0},\Sigma_{0})italic_p ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is limiting, for instance because it precludes multimodal priors. We relax it by representing p⁢(θ∗)𝑝subscript𝜃p(\theta_{*})italic_p ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by a diffusion model, which we call a diffusion model prior. We propose an efficient posterior sampling approximation for this prior where the prior and empirical evidence are mixed similarly to (3) and 𝙸𝚁𝙻𝚂𝙸𝚁𝙻𝚂\tt IRLStypewriter_IRLS (Section 4). Before we do this, we review diffusion models in Section 3.

3 Diffusion Models

A diffusion model [45, 18] is a generative model trained by diffusing samples from an unknown distribution. While multiple types of diffusion models exist [48], we adopt the probabilistic formulation and presentation of Ho et al. [18]. A diffusion model is a graphical model with T𝑇Titalic_T stages indexed by t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]italic_t ∈ [ italic_T ]. Each stage t𝑡titalic_t is associated with a latent variable St∈ℝdsubscript𝑆𝑡superscriptℝ𝑑S_{t}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A sample from the model is represented by an observed variable S0∈ℝdsubscript𝑆0superscriptℝ𝑑S_{0}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We visualize the diffusion model in Figure 1. In the forward process, the sample s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is diffused through a sequence of variables S1,…,STsubscript𝑆1…subscript𝑆𝑇S_{1},\dots,S_{T}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This process is used to learn the reverse process, where the sample s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is generated through a sequence of variables ST,…,S0subscript𝑆𝑇…subscript𝑆0S_{T},\dots,S_{0}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. To sample s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the posterior (Section 4), we add a random variable H𝐻Hitalic_H, which represents partial information about s0subscript𝑠0s_{0}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We introduce forward and reverse diffusion processes next. Learning of the reverse process is described in Appendix B. While this is a critical component of diffusion models, it is not necessary to introduce our posterior approximations.

4 Posterior Sampling

This section is organized as follows. We derive a general posterior distribution for a chain of random variables conditioned on observations in Section 4.1. After that, in Sections 4.2 and 4.4, we specialize it to the observation models in Section 2.

The algorithm that samples from the posterior distribution in Theorem 2 is presented in Algorithm 2. Our approximation has several notable properties. First, (1−α¯t)/α¯t→0→1subscript¯𝛼𝑡subscript¯𝛼𝑡0\sqrt{(1-\bar{\alpha}_{t})/\bar{\alpha}_{t}}\to 0square-root start_ARG ( 1 - over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG → 0 as t→1→𝑡1t\to 1italic_t → 1. Therefore, it becomes more precise in later stages of the reverse process. Second, in the absence of evidence hℎhitalic_h, the approximation vanishes, and all posterior distributions in Theorem 2 reduce to the priors in (5). Finally, as the number of observations increases, sampling from the posterior in Theorem 2 is asymptotically consistent.

The bound in Theorem 3 can be interpreted as follows. The sampled parameter θ~~𝜃\tilde{\theta}over~ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG approaches the true unknown parameter θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the number of observations N𝑁Nitalic_N increases. This lower bound can be attained in linear models by choosing feature vectors according to the D-optimal design [38]. Since our proof is asymptotic, we can neglect some finite-time errors and this simplifies the argument.

4.4 GLM Posterior

The Laplace approximation in GLMs (Section 2.2) naturally generalizes the exact posterior distribution in linear models (Section 2.1). We generalize Theorem 2 to GLMs along the same lines.

where θ˙t,Σ˙t←𝙸𝚁𝙻𝚂⁢(μt⁢(st)/α¯t−1,Σt/α¯t−1,h)←subscript˙𝜃𝑡subscript˙Σ𝑡𝙸𝚁𝙻𝚂subscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡subscript¯𝛼𝑡1subscriptΣ𝑡subscript¯𝛼𝑡1ℎ\dot{\theta}_{t},\dot{\Sigma}_{t}\leftarrow{\tt IRLS}(\mu_{t}(s_{t})/\sqrt{% \bar{\alpha}_{t-1}},\Sigma_{t}/\bar{\alpha}_{t-1},h)over˙ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over˙ start_ARG roman_Σ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ← typewriter_IRLS ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / square-root start_ARG over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_h ).

Proof.

The proof is in Section A.4 and comprises four steps. First, we fix t𝑡titalic_t and apply approximation (6). Second, we reparameterize the prior, from a function of stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to a function of st/α¯tsubscript𝑠𝑡subscript¯𝛼𝑡s_{t}/\sqrt{\bar{\alpha}_{t}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Third, we combine the likelihood with the prior using the Laplace approximation. Finally, we repameterize the posterior, from a function of st/α¯tsubscript𝑠𝑡subscript¯𝛼𝑡s_{t}/\sqrt{\bar{\alpha}_{t}}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / square-root start_ARG over¯ start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG to a function of stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. ∎

Similarly to Theorem 2, the distributions in Theorem 4 mix evidence with the diffusion model prior. However, this is done implicitly in 𝙸𝚁𝙻𝚂𝙸𝚁𝙻𝚂\tt IRLStypewriter_IRLS. The posterior can be sampled from using 𝙻𝚊𝚙𝚕𝚊𝚌𝚎𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙻𝚊𝚙𝚕𝚊𝚌𝚎𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt LaplaceDPStypewriter_LaplaceDPS, where the mean and covariances would be taken from Theorem 4. Note that Theorem 2 is a special case of Theorem 4 where the mean function g𝑔gitalic_g is an identity.

5 Application to Contextual Bandits

Now we apply our posterior sampling approximations (Section 4) to contextual bandits. A contextual bandit [28, 31] is a classic model for sequential decision making under uncertainty where the agent takes actions conditioned on context. We denote the action set by 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}caligraphic_A and the context set by 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. The mean reward of action a∈𝒜𝑎𝒜a\in\mathcal{A}italic_a ∈ caligraphic_A in context x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in\mathcal{X}italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X is r⁢(x,a;θ∗)𝑟𝑥𝑎subscript𝜃r(x,a;\theta_{*})italic_r ( italic_x , italic_a ; italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where r:𝒳×𝒜×Θ→ℝ:𝑟→𝒳𝒜Θℝr:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}\times\Theta\to\mathbb{R}italic_r : caligraphic_X × caligraphic_A × roman_Θ → blackboard_R is some reward function and θ∗∈Θsubscript𝜃Θ\theta_{*}\in\Thetaitalic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_Θ is an unknown model parameter (Section 2). The agent interacts with the bandit for n𝑛nitalic_n rounds indexed by k∈[n]𝑘delimited-[]𝑛k\in[n]italic_k ∈ [ italic_n ]. In round k𝑘kitalic_k, the agent observes a context xk∈𝒳subscript𝑥𝑘𝒳x_{k}\in\mathcal{X}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_X, takes an action ak∈𝒜subscript𝑎𝑘𝒜a_{k}\in\mathcal{A}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_A, and observes a stochastic reward yk=r⁢(xk,ak;θ∗)+εksubscript𝑦𝑘𝑟subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝜃subscript𝜀𝑘y_{k}=r(x_{k},a_{k};\theta_{*})+\varepsilon_{k}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where εksubscript𝜀𝑘\varepsilon_{k}italic_ε start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent zero-mean σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-sub-Gaussian noise for σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0italic_σ > 0. The goal of the agent is to maximize its cumulative reward in n𝑛nitalic_n rounds, or equivalently to minimize its cumulative regret. We define the n𝑛nitalic_n-round regret as R⁢(n)=∑k=1n𝔼⁢[r⁢(xk,ak,∗;θ∗)−r⁢(xk,ak;θ∗)]𝑅𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑛𝔼delimited-[]𝑟subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝜃𝑟subscript𝑥𝑘subscript𝑎𝑘subscript𝜃R(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}\mathbb{E}\left[r(x_{k},a_{k,*};\theta_{*})-r(x_{k},a_{k};% \theta_{*})\right]italic_R ( italic_n ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_r ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_r ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ], where ak,∗subscript𝑎𝑘a_{k,*}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k , ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the optimal action in round k𝑘kitalic_k.

Arguably the most popular approach to solving contextual bandit problems is Thompson sampling [49, 11, 3]. The key idea in TS is to use the posterior distribution of θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to explore. This is done as follows. In round k𝑘kitalic_k, the model parameter is drawn from the posterior, θ~k∼p(⋅∣hk)\tilde{\theta}_{k}\sim p(\cdot\mid h_{k})over~ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ italic_p ( ⋅ ∣ italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (2), where hksubscriptℎ𝑘h_{k}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the history of all interactions up to round k𝑘kitalic_k. After that, the agent takes the action with the highest mean reward under θ~ksubscript~𝜃𝑘\tilde{\theta}_{k}over~ start_ARG italic_θ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The pseudo-code of this algorithm is given in Algorithm 3.

A linear bandit [13, 1] is a contextual bandit with a linear reward function r⁢(x,a;θ∗)=ϕ⁢(x,a)⊤⁢θ∗𝑟𝑥𝑎subscript𝜃italic-ϕsuperscript𝑥𝑎topsubscript𝜃r(x,a;\theta_{*})=\phi(x,a)^{\top}\theta_{*}italic_r ( italic_x , italic_a ; italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_ϕ ( italic_x , italic_a ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ϕ:𝒳×𝒜→ℝd:italic-ϕ→𝒳𝒜superscriptℝ𝑑\phi:\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{A}\to\mathbb{R}^{d}italic_ϕ : caligraphic_X × caligraphic_A → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a feature extractor. The feature extractor can be non-linear in x𝑥xitalic_x and a𝑎aitalic_a. Therefore, linear bandits can be applied to non-linear functions in x𝑥xitalic_x and a𝑎aitalic_a. The feature extractor can be hand-designed or learned [39]. To simplify notation, we let ϕℓ=ϕ⁢(xℓ,aℓ)subscriptitalic-ϕℓitalic-ϕsubscript𝑥ℓsubscript𝑎ℓ\phi_{\ell}=\phi(x_{\ell},a_{\ell})italic_ϕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ϕ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) be the feature vector of the action in round k𝑘kitalic_k. When the prior distribution is a Gaussian, p⁢(θ∗)=𝒩⁢(θ∗;θ0,Σ0)𝑝subscript𝜃𝒩subscript𝜃subscript𝜃0subscriptΣ0p(\theta_{*})=\mathcal{N}(\theta_{*};\theta_{0},\Sigma_{0})italic_p ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = caligraphic_N ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ; italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the posterior in round k𝑘kitalic_k is a Gaussian in (3) for h=hkℎsubscriptℎ𝑘h=h_{k}italic_h = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. When the prior is a diffusion model, we propose sampling from

where μ^tsubscript^𝜇𝑡\hat{\mu}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Σ^tsubscript^Σ𝑡\hat{\Sigma}_{t}over^ start_ARG roman_Σ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in 𝙻𝚊𝚙𝚕𝚊𝚌𝚎𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙻𝚊𝚙𝚕𝚊𝚌𝚎𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt LaplaceDPStypewriter_LaplaceDPS are set according to Theorem 2. A generalized linear bandit [16, 23, 32, 25] is an extension of linear bandits to generalized linear models (Section 2.2). When the prior distribution is a diffusion model, we propose sampling from (9), where μ^tsubscript^𝜇𝑡\hat{\mu}_{t}over^ start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Σ^tsubscript^Σ𝑡\hat{\Sigma}_{t}over^ start_ARG roman_Σ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in 𝙻𝚊𝚙𝚕𝚊𝚌𝚎𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙻𝚊𝚙𝚕𝚊𝚌𝚎𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt LaplaceDPStypewriter_LaplaceDPS are set according to Theorem 4.

6 Experiments

We conduct three experiments: synthetic problems in 2222 dimensions (Sections 6.2 and C.1), a recommender system (Section 6.3), and a classification problem (Section C.2). In addition, we conduct an ablation study in Section C.3, where we vary the number of training samples for the diffusion prior and the number of diffusion stages T𝑇Titalic_T.

6.1 Experimental Setup

We have four baselines. Three baselines are variants of contextual Thompson sampling [11, 3]: with an uninformative Gaussian prior (𝚃𝚂𝚃𝚂\tt TStypewriter_TS), a learned Gaussian prior (𝚃𝚞𝚗𝚎𝚍𝚃𝚂𝚃𝚞𝚗𝚎𝚍𝚃𝚂\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS), and a learned Gaussian mixture prior (𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS) [21]. The last baseline is diffusion posterior sampling (𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS) of Chung et al. [12]. We implement all TS baselines as described in Section 5. The uninformative prior is 𝒩⁢(𝟎d,Id)𝒩subscript0𝑑subscript𝐼𝑑\mathcal{N}(\mathbf{0}_{d},I_{d})caligraphic_N ( bold_0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). 𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS is used only in linear bandit experiments because the logistic regression variant does not exist. The TS baselines are chosen to cover various levels of prior information. Our implementation of 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS is described in Appendix D. We also experimented with frequentist baselines, such as 𝙻𝚒𝚗𝚄𝙲𝙱𝙻𝚒𝚗𝚄𝙲𝙱\tt LinUCBtypewriter_LinUCB [1] and the ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε-greedy policy. They performed worse than 𝚃𝚂𝚃𝚂\tt TStypewriter_TS and thus we do not report them here.

Each experiment is set up as follows. First, the prior distribution of θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is specified: it can be synthetic or estimated from real-world data. Second, we learn this distribution from 10 0001000010\,00010 000 samples from it. In 𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS and 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS, we follow Appendix B. The number of stages is T=100𝑇100T=100italic_T = 100 and the diffusion factor is αt=0.97subscript𝛼𝑡0.97\alpha_{t}=0.97italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.97. Since 0.97100≈0.05superscript0.971000.050.97^{100}\approx 0.050.97 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 100 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≈ 0.05, most of the information in the training samples is diffused. The regressor in Appendix B is a 2222-layer neural network with ReLU activations. In 𝚃𝚞𝚗𝚎𝚍𝚃𝚂𝚃𝚞𝚗𝚎𝚍𝚃𝚂\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS, we fit the mean and covariance using maximum likelihood estimation. In 𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS, we fit the Gaussian mixture using scikit-learn. All algorithms are evaluated on θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sampled from the true prior.

6.2 Synthetic Experiment

The first experiment is on three synthetic problems. Each problem is a linear bandit (Section 5) with K=100𝐾100K=100italic_K = 100 actions in d=2𝑑2d=2italic_d = 2 dimensions. The reward noise is σ=2𝜎2\sigma=2italic_σ = 2. The feature vectors of actions are sampled uniformly at random from a unit ball. The prior distributions of θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are shown in Figure 2. The first is a mixture of two Gaussians and the last can be approximated well by a mixture of two Gaussians. 𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS is implemented with two mixture components, which can exactly represent the first prior and approximate the last one well.

Our results are reported in Figure 2. We observe two main trends. First, samples from the diffusion prior closely resemble those from the true prior. In such cases, 𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS is expected to perform well and even outperforms 𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS, because it has a better representation of the prior. We observe this in all problems. Second, 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS diverges as the number of rounds increases. This is because 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS relies on the score of the likelihood of observations (Section 7), which tends to infinity as the number of observations increases. This happens despite tuning (Appendix D). We report results on additional synthetic problems in Section C.1.

𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS should be T𝑇Titalic_T times more computationally costly than 𝚃𝚂𝚃𝚂\tt TStypewriter_TS with a Gaussian prior (Section 4.2). We observe this empirically. As an example, the average cost of 100100100100 runs of 𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS on any problem in Figure 2 is 12121212 seconds. The average cost of 𝚃𝚂𝚃𝚂\tt TStypewriter_TS is 0.10.10.10.1 seconds. The computation and accuracy can be traded off, and we investigate this in Section C.3. In Problem \saycross, we vary the number of diffusion stages from T=1𝑇1T=1italic_T = 1 to T=300𝑇300T=300italic_T = 300. We observe that the computational cost is linear in T𝑇Titalic_T and the regret drops quickly from around 85858585 at T=1𝑇1T=1italic_T = 1 to 50505050 at T=25𝑇25T=25italic_T = 25.

6.3 MovieLens Experiment

In the second experiment, we learn to recommend an item to randomly arriving users. The problem is simulated using the MovieLens 1M dataset [27], with 1111 million ratings for 3 70637063\,7063 706 movies from 6 04060406\,0406 040 users. As a first step, we subtract the mean rating from all ratings and complete the sparse rating matrix M𝑀Mitalic_M by alternating least squares [14] with rank d=5𝑑5d=5italic_d = 5. The learned factorization is M=U⁢V⊤𝑀𝑈superscript𝑉topM=UV^{\top}italic_M = italic_U italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The i𝑖iitalic_i-th row of U𝑈Uitalic_U, denoted by Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, represents user i𝑖iitalic_i. The j𝑗jitalic_j-th row of V𝑉Vitalic_V, denoted by Vjsubscript𝑉𝑗V_{j}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, represents movie j𝑗jitalic_j. We use the item embeddings Vjsubscript𝑉𝑗V_{j}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as unknown model parameters and the user embeddings Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as features of the actions.

We experiment with both linear and logistic bandits. In both, an item is initially chosen randomly from Vjsubscript𝑉𝑗V_{j}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and K=10𝐾10K=10italic_K = 10 random actions are chosen from Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in each round. In the linear bandit, the mean reward for recommending item j𝑗jitalic_j to user i𝑖iitalic_i is Ui⊤⁢Vjsuperscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖topsubscript𝑉𝑗U_{i}^{\top}V_{j}italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The reward noise is σ=0.75𝜎0.75\sigma=0.75italic_σ = 0.75 and estimated from data. In the logistic bandit, the mean reward is g⁢(Ui⊤⁢Vj)𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑈𝑖topsubscript𝑉𝑗g(U_{i}^{\top}V_{j})italic_g ( italic_U start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where g𝑔gitalic_g is a sigmoid.

Our MovieLens results are shown in Figure 3. We observe the same trends as in Section 6.2. First, samples from the diffusion prior closely resemble those from the true prior (Figure 3a). Since the problem is higher dimensional, we visualize the overlap using a UMAP projection [44]. Second, 𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS has a significantly lower regret than all baselines, in both linear (Figure 3b) and logistic (Figure 3c) bandits. Finally, 𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂𝙼𝚒𝚡𝚃𝚂\tt MixTStypewriter_MixTS barely outperforms 𝚃𝚞𝚗𝚎𝚍𝚃𝚂𝚃𝚞𝚗𝚎𝚍𝚃𝚂\tt TunedTStypewriter_TunedTS. We observe this trend consistently in higher dimensions, which motivated our work on online learning with more complex priors.

7 Related Work

There are two lines of related works: bandits with diffusion models and posterior sampling in diffusion models. We start with the former. Hsieh et al. [22] proposed Thompson sampling with a diffusion model prior for K𝐾Kitalic_K-armed bandits. We consider a more general setting of contextual bandits and also develop new posterior sampling approximations for it. Aouali [4] proposed and analyzed contextual bandits with a linear diffusion model prior: μt⁢(st)subscript𝜇𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡\mu_{t}(s_{t})italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) in (5) is linear in stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and q⁢(s0)𝑞subscript𝑠0q(s_{0})italic_q ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a Gaussian. Due to this assumption, the resulting model is just a linear Gaussian model and not a general diffusion model, as in our work.

The closest related work on posterior sampling in diffusion models is 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS of Chung et al. [12]. The key idea in 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS is to sample from a diffusion model posterior by adding the score of the likelihood of observations to it. In our notation, this is ∇log⁡p⁢(h∣θ)∇𝑝conditionalℎ𝜃\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)∇ roman_log italic_p ( italic_h ∣ italic_θ ), where p⁢(h∣θ)𝑝conditionalℎ𝜃p(h\mid\theta)italic_p ( italic_h ∣ italic_θ ) is defined in Assumptions 1 and 2. Note that ∇log⁡p⁢(h∣θ)∇𝑝conditionalℎ𝜃\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)∇ roman_log italic_p ( italic_h ∣ italic_θ ) grows linearly in N𝑁Nitalic_N. Therefore, 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS becomes unstable as N→∞→𝑁N\to\inftyitalic_N → ∞. See our empirical results in Section 6.2 and the implementation of 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS in Appendix D, which was tuned to improve its stability. Other methods for posterior sampling in diffusion models have been proposed recently: a sequential Monte Carlo approximation for the conditional reverse process [52], a variant of 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS with an uninformative prior [37], a pseudo-inverse approximation to the likelihood of evidence [47], and posterior sampling in latent diffusion models [40]. All of these methods rely on the score of the likelihood ∇log⁡p⁢(h∣θ)∇𝑝conditionalℎ𝜃\nabla\log p(h\mid\theta)∇ roman_log italic_p ( italic_h ∣ italic_θ ) and thus become unstable as the number of observations N𝑁Nitalic_N increases. Our posterior approximations do not have this issue because they are based on the product of prior and evidence distributions (Theorems 2 and 4), and thus gradient-free. They work well across different levels of uncertainty (Section 6) and do not require tuning.

We also wanted to note that posterior sampling is a special from of guiding generation in diffusion models. Other approaches include conditional pre-training [15], a constraint in the reverse process [17], refining the null-space content [50], solving an optimization problem that pushes the reverse process towards evidence [46], and aligning the reverse process with the prompt [7].

8 Conclusions

We propose posterior sampling approximations for diffusion models priors. These approximations are contextual, and can be implemented efficiently in linear models and GLMs. We analyze them and evaluate them empirically on contextual bandit problems.

Our work focuses on developing novel posterior approximations rather than a regret analysis. This is because the existing approximations are unstable and may diverge in the online setting (Sections 7 and 6.2). A proper regret bound for 𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS would require analyzing two errors. The first error arises because the reverse process reverses the forward process only approximately (Appendix B). The second error arises because our posteriors are only approximate (Section 4.3). That being said, prior works already provided general insights on the utility of complex priors. For instance, Russo and Van Roy [42] proved a O⁢(Γ⁢H⁢(A∗)⁢n)𝑂Γ𝐻subscript𝐴𝑛O(\sqrt{\Gamma H(A_{*})n})italic_O ( square-root start_ARG roman_Γ italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_n end_ARG ) regret bound for a linear bandit, where ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ is the maximum ratio of regret to information gain and H⁢(A∗)𝐻subscript𝐴H(A_{*})italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the entropy of the distribution of the optimal action under the prior. In short, the bound says that a lower entropy H⁢(A∗)𝐻subscript𝐴H(A_{*})italic_H ( italic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), which reflects how concentrated the prior is, yields a lower regret.

Finally, we believe that our ideas can be extended beyond GLMs. The key idea in Section 4.4 is to use the Laplace approximation of the likelihood. This approximation can be computed exactly in GLMs. More generally though, it is a good approximation whenever the likelihood can be approximated well by a single Gaussian distribution. By the central limit theorem, under appropriate conditions, this is expected for any observation model when the number of observations is large.

A.4 Proof of Theorem 4

This proof has two parts.

Appendix C Additional Experiments

This section contains three additional experiments.

C.1 Additional Synthetic Problems

In Section 6.2, we show results for three hand-selected problems out of six. We report results on the other three problems in Figure 4. We observe the same trends as in Section 6.2. The only minor change is that 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS does not diverge on the last problem.

C.2 MNIST Experiment

The next experiment is on the MNIST dataset [30], where the mean reward is estimated by a classifier. We start with learning an MLP-based multi-way classifier for digits and extract d=8𝑑8d=8italic_d = 8 dimensional embeddings of all digits in the dataset, which are used as feature vectors in our experiment. We generate a distribution over model parameters θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows: (1) we choose a random positive label, assign it reward 1111, and assign reward −11-1- 1 to all other labels; (2) we subsample a random dataset of size 20202020, with 50%percent5050\%50 % positive and 50%percent5050\%50 % negative labels; (3) we train a linear model, which gives us a single θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We repeat this 10 0001000010\,00010 000 times and get a distribution over θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We consider both linear and logistic bandits. In both, the model parameter θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is initially sampled from the prior. In each round, K=10𝐾10K=10italic_K = 10 random actions are chosen randomly from all digits. In the linear bandit, the mean reward for digit x𝑥xitalic_x is x⊤⁢θ∗superscript𝑥topsubscript𝜃x^{\top}\theta_{*}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the reward noise is σ=1𝜎1\sigma=1italic_σ = 1. In the logistic bandit, the mean reward is g⁢(x⊤⁢θ∗)𝑔superscript𝑥topsubscript𝜃g(x^{\top}\theta_{*})italic_g ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where g𝑔gitalic_g is a sigmoid.

Our MNIST results are reported in Figure 5. We observe again that 𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂𝙳𝚒𝚏𝚏𝚃𝚂\tt DiffTStypewriter_DiffTS has a lower regret than all baselines, because the learned prior captures the underlying distribution of θ∗subscript𝜃\theta_{*}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT well. We note that both the prior and diffusion prior distributions exhibit a strong cluster structure (Figure 5a), where each cluster represents one label.

C.3 Ablation Studies

We conduct three ablation studies on the cross problem in Figure 2.

In all experiments, the number of samples for training diffusion priors was 10 0001000010\,00010 000. In Figure 6a, we vary it from 100100100100 to 10 0001000010\,00010 000. We observe that the regret decreases as the number of samples increases, due to learning a more accurate prior approximation. It stabilizes around 3 00030003\,0003 000 training samples. We conclude that the quality of the learned prior approximation has a major impact on regret.

In all experiments, the number of diffusion stages was T=100𝑇100T=100italic_T = 100. In Figure 6b, we vary it from 1111 to 300300300300 and observe its impact on regret. The regret at T=1𝑇1T=1italic_T = 1 is high, but then it drops quickly up to T=25𝑇25T=25italic_T = 25. It stabilizes around T=100𝑇100T=100italic_T = 100, which we used in our experiments. In Figure 6c, we vary T𝑇Titalic_T from 1111 to 300300300300 and observe its impact on the computation time of posterior sampling. As suggested in Section 4.2, it increases linearly with T𝑇Titalic_T. The main contribution to the computation time are T𝑇Titalic_T calls to the neural network regressor.

While this significantly improves the performance of 𝙳𝙿𝚂𝙳𝙿𝚂\tt DPStypewriter_DPS, it does not prevent failures. The fundamental problem is that gradient-based optimization is sensitive to the step size, especially when the optimized function is steep. We do not have any such hyper-parameter in our algorithm.
